awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Ecomorphological diversification and the origin of phenotypic disparity in crocodile-line archosaurs
awd_abstract_narration:
Species morphology typically evolves to meet the demands of the environment. In the fossil record, and among existing species, large morphological changes are frequently associated with changes in habitat or ecology. However, there remains little understanding of the general rules that govern morphological change associated with ecological change. This project will use skeletal and soft-tissue anatomy as well as detailed 3D shape data to study closely-related, transitional species to investigate the evolution of morphology and ecology in the long-lived and fossil-rich group Crocodylomorpha (crocodiles, alligators, and their extinct relatives). The project will exploit the group's multiple natural experimentation with extreme environments to develop detailed conceptual models for major ecological and morphological transitions that will inform on the rules underlying morphological change. These models will then serve as predictors for how and why transformations occur, which can be tested in other groups with similar narratives. Important examples include the initial emergence of four-limbed vertebrates onto land, how birds took the sky, and the first steps in the reign of mammals. The innovative technologies, techniques, and widely applicable conclusions from this research will promote interdisciplinary work among paleontologists, biomechanists, ecologists, and evolutionary biologists.  The researchers will make their data, digital models, analytical tools, and essential supplementary files available for wide access. Furthermore, this project will support associated PhD and Postdoctoral research as well as foster access to higher education for substantially underrepresented groups.

This project will use integrative approaches to reveal the complexities of ecomorphological changes across major evolutionary transitions. The study will examine how novel environments put new, often extreme demands on historical phenotypes by addressing how large-scale habitat and ecological transitions drive evolution across multiple integrated anatomical systems. The research will test hypotheses about phenotypic integration on an evolutionary scale to determine whether developmental rates, sequence heterochrony, and/or patterns of modularity determine if consistently applied rules of ecomorphological diversification underlie adaptive radiations. The outcome will be an unprecedented database of crocodylomorph cranial and post-cranial diversity that includes contrast-enhanced neural and skeletal tissues, raw and partitioned CT stacks, and 3D digital models as well as comparative, intra-clade conceptual models for how predatory vertebrates shift to lives on the shoreline, within the sea, and toward herbivory. The microCT and cutting-edge, diffusible iodine-based contrast-enhanced computed tomography imaging, in addition to a robust morphological phylogeny for analysis of evolutionary trends using the latest phylogenetic methods, represent potentially transformative methodologies developed by this research group.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Tens of thousands of animal species blanket the planet, and a primary question facing biologists is: how did all of this diversity come about? The answer involves unraveling the biological principles that drive evolution. In this project, we studied crocodylians and their extinct ancestors as a model group to address this question. Crocodylomorphs have a long evolutionary history rich in fossil specimens, spanning over 230 million years. This history includes small, bipedal insect-eaters, enormous carnivores, open-ocean hunters, fish-eating specialists, semi-aquatic ambush predators, and armored herbivores. Critically, there are living species for which ecology, behavior, and anatomy are well understood, which the research team used to interpret specimens from the fossil record.

For this project, exceptionally well-preserved crocodylomorphs were scanned using micro-computed tomography and cutting-edge, new soft- tissue imaging tools. From these, the research team created virtualized models of crocodylomorph skeletal and brain anatomy, including brain anatomy from 200-million-year-old fossils. The team tracked changes in these features across important shifts in crocodylomorph diversification to identify "rules" that underpin skeletal and nervous system changes associated with major environmental shifts. Because the team developed digital representations of crocodylomorph traits, they studied these features in 3D using multivariate statistics that capture shape variation. Altogether, this enabled the investigators to test hypotheses about which factors best explain evolutionary changes, including developmental rate, the order of developmental sequences, integration of anatomical regions, relatedness between species, and environment.

The study showed that habitat preferences explain more than half of the differences in brain and skeletal features of crocodylomorphs. Next, developmental rate accounts for about one-third of differences, and which species are related to each other explains the rest. These findings paint a complex picture of diversity and show the influence of numerous biological factors.

So, how did crocodylomorph diversity come about? It seems to result from occupying environments in and around the water's edge. This made it easier for land-based crocodylomorphs to exploit aquatic resources and for aquatic crocodylomorphs to exploit land-based resources. When one lineage was especially good at making the switch in environment, it did so, resulting in the evolution of several new species along the way, which also diversified via unique pathways. This process often initially occurred by changing developmental rates across different body parts, and it was most common to observe similar changes in species that were each others' closest relatives. As a model group, the pattern shown by crocodylomorphs suggests that it is essential to study evolution and diversity in the context of environment (including paleo- environment) and development. Without these perspectives, future research teams may be unable to unravel the complexities of how diversification happens in other vertebrate groups.

Sampling hundreds of specimens is needed to study big-picture biological questions. An undertaking of this scale could not be accomplished without a large team, and the investigators specifically recruited early-career scientists, high school students, undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral scholars to contribute to, and learn from, this research. Building STEM talent by combining rigorous training with novel research opportunities is critical for developing a scientifically literate workforce and society. This project saw the contribution of more than a dozen early-career scientists contributing datasets, analyses, presentations, and publications to the research effort. Student participants wrote science fair projects, presented posters, gave lectures, wrote manuscripts, and undertook theses and dissertations that helped establish and advance their careers. Postdoctoral scholars gained important project management and personnel mentoring experience that also helped them become competitive for full-time employment as lead investigators

One substantial outcome of this project is the volume of imaging data, such as computed tomography scans, that it has produced for modern and fossilized crocodylomorphs. As they are finalized, these datasets continue to be uploaded to open-access online repositories, such as Morphosource, where they can be accessed by scientists and non-scientists alike. Advancements in data access will propel the next generation of educators and researchers into a new, data-rich scientific landscape. This will significantly benefit scientific reproducibility and the synthesis of new ideas based on the additive value of large-data studies. This project is contributing to the long-term success of that vision.

 


Last Modified: 12/04/2023
Modified by: Alan H Turner

Image
  • False-colored brain models from a crocodile in 3D: Top is a side view (snout is leftward); Bottom is a top-down view (snout is leftward); Middle is a contrast-enhanced computed tomography mid-section, which is the basis for the brain models and shows the brain highlighted blue (snout is rightward).
    Paul Gignac
    Copyrighted
    Alan H Turner
    Crocodylian Brain in 3D
